basics.title: The array is used to define sets of calorimetric data.

id.description: The id represents a specific calorimetric data set.

name.description: If the calorimetric data set has a name, it can be indicated here.

explanation.description: This string can explain humans the calorimetric data set.

warnings.description: Some calorimetric data may easily be misinterpreted. The warnings contain critical information for users to avoid typical mistakes.

origin.description: For traceability, the origin of the data can be defined.

approvals.description: If the calorimetric data is approved by stakeholders, a signature can be provided.

created.description: When the calorimetric data was created.

valid.description: From when and until when the data is valid.

characteristics.description: This section defines characteristics which are constant for this calorimetric data set.

file.description: The optical data can be provided as a file. If the data is provided as a file and as explicit values below, than it MUST be the same data only in different formats. If one data is derived from another data, it MUST be stored as separate items in the array optical/basics and origin SHOULD be used to identify the method of derivation.

fluxes.title: This array defines the energy fluxes between the sample and its surroundings.

items.description: The name of the part of the surroundings. If neither exterior nor interior or lateral fits, choose other and describe it in the explanation below.

explanation.description: This string explains humans the calorimetric data set.

convection.title: Convective heat transfer is defined by the temperature difference and the heat transfer coefficient.

flux.description: The heat flux is driven by the temperature differences. Positive heat flux means heat flux towards the sample. It is meaured in watts.

surrounding.description: The average temperature of this part of the surroundings.

sample.description: The average temperature of the part of the sample which faces this part of the surroundings.

coefficient.description: The heat transfer coefficient equals the heat flux divided by the temperature difference. It has the unit watt per square meter per kelvin.

fluid.title: If heat is transfered to the sample by a fluid circuit, this heat flux can be defined by the following properties.

flux.description: This heat flux is caused by the temperature difference between the fluid inlet of the sample and the fluid outlet. It is meaured in watts.

inlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the inlet of the sample.

outlet.description: The average temperature of the fluid at the outlet of the sample.

massFlow.description: The mass flow of the fluid circuit which enters and leaves the sample in kilogram per second.

specificHeatCapacity.description: The specific heat capacity of the fluid in joules per kilogram per Kelvin.

flux.description: The irradiance is determined on the surface of the sample. Positive irradiance means irradiance towards the sample. It is meaured in watts.

direction.description: The direction of the irradiance on the sample.

flux.description: The electric energy supplied to the sample. Positive electric energy means that it is delivered to the sample.

currentVoltage.description: The current-voltage characteristic can be important for example for photovoltaics. It can also be used just to define just one current and one voltage.

results.title: The results of a calorimetric measurement depend on the reference area. This array can defined results for different reference areas.

area.title: The results depend on the area of the component which is used to calculate the results. This section defines this area.

items.description: (i) `centre` means that the results are valid for the centre of the component without influence by the frame. This is important for example for glazings. (ii) `outerDimensions` means that the whole area of the outer dimensions of the component is considered for the results. (iii) `irradiatedAbsorber` means that the area of the photovoltaic or solar thermal absober, which is irradiated by direct irradiance, is used to calculate the results. (iv) For the case of direct irradiance, `projectedIrradiatedAbsorber` projects the directly irradiated absorber area to a plane which is perpendicular to the direct irradiance. (v) If none of the other categories apply, `explanation` below must be used to describe the category.

explanation.description: If `other` is chosen as category above, the area needs to be defined by this explanation. For any other category, the explanation can add details.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior.

gValue.description: The g value is also known as Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC), Solar Factor or Total Solar Energy Transmittance. It can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior. It has typically values between 0 and 1 and is a measure for the fraction of solar energy which enters the building.

photovoltaic.description: The photovoltaic efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide electric power. This efficiency has no units.

solarThermal.description: The solar thermal efficiency of a component which uses irradiance to provide heat.

items.description: Either a measurement aims at quasi-stationary conditions or at dynamic conditions where the values change over time.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

uValue.description: The U value, also known as thermal transmittance, can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior.

gValue.description: The g value is also known as Solar Heat Gain Coefficient (SHGC), Solar Factor or Total Solar Energy Transmittance. It can be calculated by dividing the heat flux through the sample by the temperature difference between the exterior and the interior. It has typically values between 0 and 1 and is a measure for the fraction of solar energy which enters the building.

basics.title: The array is used to define sets of optical data.

id.description: The id represents the optical data set.

name.description: If the optical data set has a name, it can be indicated here.

explanation.description: This string can explain humans the optical data set.

warnings.description: Some optical data may easily be misinterpreted. The warnings contain critical information for users to avoid typical mistakes.

origin.description: For traceability, the origin of the data can be defined.

approvals.description: If the optical data is approved by stakeholders, a signature can be provided.

created.description: When the optical data was created.

valid.description: From when and until when the data is valid.

globalCharacteristicsComponent.description: If one of the characteristics of a component is valid for all 'dataPoints', then this characteristic MUST be defined here and MUST NOT be defined in `dataPoints/characteristicsComponent'.

file.description: The optical data can be provided as a file. If the data is provided as a file and as explicit values below, than it MUST be the same data only in different formats. If one data is derived from another data, it MUST be stored as separate items in the array optical/basics and origin SHOULD be used to identify the method of derivation.

dataPoints.title: This section provides a list of all data points of this optical data.

items.title: Each optical data point consists of a definition of the incident radiation, the variables of the component, the emergent rediation and the optical results.

incidence.description: This section defines the incident radiation on the component.

characteristicsComponent.description: If a characteristic of a component varies between 'dataPoints', then this characteristic MUST be defined here and MUST NOT be defined in `optical/globalCharacteristicsComponent'.

emergence.description: This section defines the radiation which emerges from the component.

results.description: Results can be for example the transmittance and the reflectance.

direction.title: This section defines a direction for example of the radiation on a sample. The array offers different ways of describing the direction, for example by two angles.

polar.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the polar angle is measured from a fixed axis such as the z-axis of a cartesian coordinate system.

azimuth.description: In the spherical coordinate system, the azimuth angle is measured from orthogonal projextion of the direction on a reference plane such as the plane between the x- and y-axis of a cartestian coordinate system.

xz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope and the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade,then the angle xz is measured from the z-axis towards the x-axis. 80° is then from the facade almost vertically upwards and -10° means from the facade downwards, but almost horizontal.

yz.description: If the z-axis is normal to the building envelope, the x-axis directs for example vertically upwards in a facade and the y-axis is horizontal in an right-handed coordinate system, then the angle yz is measured from the z-axis towards the y axis. From the facade looking to the exterior, 80° means a direction far right, almost parallel to the facade. -10° means from the facade to exterior slightly left, but almost perpendiculat to the facade.

incidence.description: If the sample has a rotational symmetry, then the incidence angle is sufficient to define the direction.

profile.description: If the sample has a profile angle symmetry, then the profile angle is sufficient to define the direction. The profile angle is the projection of the altitude angle of the incidence on a vertical plane which is perpendicular to the surface of the sample.

anyOf.title: This section should be used for cases with nearnormal or hemispherical incidence or emergence. For other cases, the other items of the array `direction` should be used.

items.description: Nearnormal means a direction almost perpendicular to the sample surface. Hemispherical means all directions into the hemisphere above the sample surface, for example when there is the same irradiance from all directions. Diffuse means all directions except the nearnormal direction. For example, the nearnormal-hemispherical transmittance is always equal to the nearnormal-nearnormal transmittance plus the nearnormal-diffuse transmittance.

formatting.description: The definition of the format of the array below needs to specify how the items of the array can be interpreted as a list of directions. For example, the format can define that the list consists of pairs of polar and azimuth angles.

items.description: In order to reduze the size of the data, multiple directions can be entered as a list/array.

polarisation.title: Polarization is a characteristic of radiation which can influence the transmittance and the reflectance. Radiation can be polarized linearly or circular.

s.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field perpendicular to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. s is usually between 0 and 1. Only in raw data there may be exceptions because of the uncertainty. However, s can never be below 0-uncertainty or larger than 1+uncertainty.

p.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field parallel to the plane of incidence of the radiation on the sample. p is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

l.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a left-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. l is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

r.description: This property represents the fraction of radiation with its electric field rotating in a right-hand sense with respect to the direction of radiation. r is usually between 0 and 1 and can never be below `0 - uncertainty` or larger than `1 + uncertainty`.

wavelengths.title: This section offers three options to define the wavelength of radiation: either as a single wavelength, as an array of wavelenghts or as an integral over many wavelengths.

wavelength.description: A single wavelength in nanometers. If necessary, the uncertainty can be defined under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/bandwidth`.

items.description: An list of wavelengths, each in nanometers. If the uncertainty is identical, it can be defined under `#/definitions/wavelength/range/bandwidth`. If the uncertainty is not identical and relevant, the array should not be used.

integral.description: This flag indicates that an integral over many wavelenthgs is considered here. Under `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/spectrum`, the spectrum can be specified over which the integral result is calculated.

range.title: The range can either define the bandwidth or amplification factor of measuring a single wavelength or an entire spectrum of wavenlengths which is measured at the same time.

bandwidth.description: When `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength` is defined as the center, bandwidth defines is the range of wavelengths around it. It can be interpreted as the uncertainty of the `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength`.

amplificationFactor.description: range/bandwidth is difficult to measure. Often it is easier to determine the amplificationFactor as a measure for the uncertainty of the `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/wavelength`.

items.description: If `#/definitions/optical/wavelengths/integral` is true, then `#/definitions/optical/wavelength/range/spectrum` identifies the spectrum of wavelengths over which the integral result is be calculated. For further specification of the spectrum, please search for the applied `#/definitions/standard`.

incidence.title: This section defines the incident radiation on a sample. It consists of the direction of the irradiance, its polarization, the wavelenthgs and the range of the wavelengths.

emergence.title: This section defines the emergent radiation on a sample. It consists of the direction of the emergence, its polarization, the wavelenthgs and the range of the wavelengths.

characteristicsComponent.title: This section defines parameters for optical measurements and simulations. The parameters are lated used either as optical/characteristics or optical/variables.

reference.description: This reference defines any treatment performed on the sample before measurement.
This reference can define the location of measurement on the sample.
This reference defines the polarization sensitivity of the receiver of the optical measurement.

instrumentSignature.description: The instrument signature is defined as the mean scatter leel detected when there is no sample scatter present.

normalization.description: The normalization methods absolute, relative, specular and diffuse reflectance are defined by ASTM E2387-05:2011.

coordinateSystem.description: The coordinate system is defined by a reference to a publication or standard.

referenceSample.description: Optical measurements can depend on the reference sample which is used. The reference defines this reference sample.

spot.description: The reference defines the size and profile of the irradiance on the sample.

tilt.description: The tilt angle for example of venetian blinds.

symmetries.description: Symmetries of the optical characteristics can be used to reduce the necessary measurements and simulations.

reference.description: A reference can be used to define which side of the component is defined as non-prime and which as prime. Often, the non-prime side faces the exterior and the prime side the interior. The reference should also define which side of the component is the top side and which is the bottom side.

explanation.description: This string can explain which side of the component is defined as nonPrime and which as prime. Often, the non-prime side faces the exterior and the prime side the interior. The string should also define which side of the component is the top side and which is the bottom side.

items.description: The item defines whether the incidence is on the nonPrime or the prime side of the sample. Both are defined under 'definitionOfSides'. If the results are the same for both sides, 'symmetric' can be used.

results.title: This section defines the results of the optical measurement or simulation under the specified boundary conditions.

oneOf.title: This is the most verbose form of exchanging optical data and the easiest to understand.

transmittance.description: Transmittance is the ratio between the irradiance which is transmitted through the sample and the irradiance on the the sample. It has values between 0 and 1. Exceptions are usually due to measurement uncertainty.

reflectance.description: Reflectance is the ratio between the irradiance which is reflected by the sample and the irradiance on the the sample.

absorptanceEmittance.description: Absorptance is the ratio between the irradiance which is absorbed by the sample and the irradiance on the the sample. Emittance is the ratio of the radiant emittance of heat of the component to that of a standard black body. For the same 'wavelenghts', the absorptance equals the emittance. For the same 'incidence', 'variables' and 'emergence', the result absorptanceEmittance can be calculated by 'absorptanceEmittance = 1 - transmittance - reflectance'.

oneOf.title: This is a less verbose form of exchanging optical data. If it is used, also the 'incidence' and 'emergence' need to use arrays and the formatting of the arrays needs to be well defined.

absorptanceEmittance.description: Absorptance is the ratio between the irradiance which is absorbed by the sample and the irradiance on the the sample. Emittance is the ratio of the radiant emittance of heat of the component to that of a standard black body. For the same 'wavelenghts', the absorptance equals the emittance. For the same 'incidence', 'variables' and 'emergence', the result absorptanceEmittance can be calculated by 'absorptanceEmittance = 1 - transmittance - reflectance'.

oneOf.title: BSDF means Bidirectional Scattering Distribution Function. It is defined as the emergent radiation PER STERADIAN divided by the incident radiation AND THE COSINE OF THE ANGLE OF EMERGENCE. Bidirectional means that the direction of the incident radiation on the sample is defined and also the direction of the emergent radiation to the detector. BSDF data often involves many data points with various combinations of incidence and emergence directions. This section defines the results of the BSDF measurement or simulation under the specified boundary conditions.

BTDF.description: BTDF means Bidirectional Transmittance Distribution Function. It is defined as the  radiation per steradian which is transmitted in a certain direction and divided by the incident radiation and the cosine of the angle of emergence.

BRDF.description: BRDF means Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function. It is defined as the  radiation per steradian which is transmitted in a certain direction and divided by the incident radiation and the cosine of the angle of emergence.

items.description: (i) A component can have an optical symmetry regarding the angle of incidence. This means that the results are the same for all directions of incidence which have the same incidence angle. (ii) Accordingly, an optical symmetry regarding the profile angle means the results are the same for all directions of incidence which have the same profile angle. The profile angle is the projection of the altitude angle of the incidence on a vertical plane which is perpendicular to the surface of the sample. (iii) In the case of a mirror symmetry, the results for one half of the possible directions of incidence are enough to determine also the results for the other half of the possible directions of incidence because the second half is a mirror image of the first half. (iv) In the case of a rotational symmetry, the results for some directions of incidence are enough to determine the results for the other directions of incidence by rotating them around the line perpendicular to the surface of the component.

component.title: This section collects the definitions regarding components of building envelopes

basics.title: This section collects the basic definitions about a component.

id.description: This id represents the component. A component as a general product has usually a central identifier. One specific instance of this component in a specific building has usually a decentral identifier.

abbreviation.description: The abbreviation of the component in Latin alphabet

explanation.description: An explanation with more details about the component

version.description: The id represents the version of the component.

relations.title: The current component can have relations to other components. These relations can range in the dimension between a very general component such as a general product and and a very concretized component such as a specific component in a specific buildling. A second dimension of relation ranges from being part of another assembled component to being an assembly of other components. A third dimension are variants of components. They share a large part of their characteristics and are not necessarily more general, more concretized or part of an assembly. In this section, these relations between components can be defined.

concretizationOf.description: The current component is a concretization of a more general component. The more general component is identified by this id.

items.description: The current component is a generalization of a more concretized component. The more concretized component is identified by this id.

The current component is neither a concretization nor a generalization nor an assembly or a part of a second component. But it is a variant of a second component. This means that the current component and the second component share a large part of their characteristics. The second component is identified by this id.
The current component is a part of an assembly of other components. Each of the other components is defined by its id.
The current component is an assembly of other components. Each of the other components is defined by its id.

categories.description: The component is categorized in order to facilitate queries.

characteristics.description: This section defines characteristics of a component which do not depend on a specific domain such as 'optical' or 'calorimetric'. Therefore, they are constant and valid for all data sets. Characteristics which may vary between data sets about this component are stored on lower levels of the structure. For example, 'optical/globalCharacteristics' defines characteristics which are specific for optical data, but do not change within one optical data set. 'optical/dataPoints/characteristicsComponent' defines characteristics which vary between dataPoints of one optical data set. This structure aims to reduce the size of the data.

owner.description: The id and description of the owner of the component

manufacturer.description: The id and description of the manufacturer of the component

developer.description: The id and description of the institution or person which developed the component

approvals.description: If the dataset for this component has been approved by an institution, this approval is specified here.

available.description: Since when and until when the component has been available

optical.description: This section is used to define and exchange optical data sets about one component. For example the transmittance and reflectance with specific boundary conditions.

calorimetric.description: This section is used to define and exchange calorimetric data sets about one component.For example the U value, the g value (or Solar Heat Gain Coefficient).

photovoltaic.title: This section is used to define and exchange photovoltaic data sets. This means building envelopes which can convert irradiance into electric power.

module.description: If the component can turn irradiance into DC current, it can be named BIPV module and defined here.

inverter.description: If the component can convert DC to AC, it can be named inverter and be defined by this section.

system.description: If the building component consists of several PV modules and an inverter, it can be named BIPV system and defined here.

categories.title: This section defines the categories which a component can have.

items.description: A building envelope component can have one or more of the following categories. (i) If the component is a plain material, for example a sheet which could be used to build a blind, the category 'material' should be used. (ii) If the component can be treated as a layer for optical simulations of a stack of layers, then the category 'layer' should be used. Venetian blinds are one example of a layer. The center-of-glazing values are important for the simulation of a stack of layers. (iii) If the width, the height and the edges of the component are well defined, then the category 'unit' should be used. For example a window with frame and shading system.

material.description: If the component has the 'componentType':'material', then it can have the material categories defined in this section.

layer.description: If the component has the 'componentType':'layer', then it can have the layer categories defined in this section.

unit.description: If the component has the 'componentType':'unit', then it can have the unit categories defined in this section.

version.title: This section provides definitions about a version of a component.

id.description: This id represents a specific version of a component.

name.description: If the version of the component has a specific name or version number, it can be entered here.

explanation.description: Here the version can be described in free text.

owner.description: The id and description of the owner of the component

manufacturer.description: The id and description of the manufacturer of the component

developer.description: The id and description of the institution or person which developed the component

available.description: Since when and until when the component has been available

characteristics.title: This section defines which characteristics a component can have which do not change between different data sets about this component.

geometry.title: This section defines the geometry of the component which can either be an assembly or a single component.

airPermeability.title: Air permeability quantifies how easy air can flow through the component.

permeabilityFactor.description: The Permeability Factor (PF) is defined by AERC 1.1 Appendix F.

colour.description: The reference offers several way to define the colour of the component.

cutOff.description: The cutoff angle is an angle above which the incident radiation cannot cause glare.

chemicalElements.description: In this array, the most important chemical elements can be named by the two letters of the periodic table of elements.

material.description: If the component is a material, the material-specific characteristics can be named here.

layer.description: If the component is a layer, the layer-specific characteristics can be named here.

unit.description: If the component is a unit, the unit-specific characteristics can be named here.

address.description: The address for example of a building, of an institution or person. It consists for example of the street, the city, the county, the postal code and the country.

building.title: This section collects definitions for buildings.

basics.title: This section is used to define a building.

id.description: This id represents the building. The identifier is issued from www.buildings.com and allows searches for all data about this building over the whole lifetime of the building.

explanation.description: An explanation with more details about the building

version.description: The id represents the version of the building.

relations.title: The current building can have relations to other buildings. These relations can range in the dimension between a very general building in early planning phases and and a very concretized building in later phases of the life cycle. A second dimension of relation ranges from being part of an assembly of buildings to being an assembly of other buildings. A third dimension are variants of buildings for example during the desing phase. The variants share a large part of their characteristics and are not necessarily more general, more concretized or part of an assembly. In this section, these relations between buildings can be defined.

concretizationOf.description: The current building is a concretization of a more general building. The more general building is identified by this id.

items.description: The current building is a generalization of a more concretized building. The more concretized building is identified by this id.

The current building is neither a concretization nor a generalization nor an assembly or a part of a second building. But it is a variant of a second building. This means that the current building and the second building share a large part of their characteristics. The second building is identified by this id.
The current building is a part of an assembly of other buildings. Each of the other buildings is defined by its id.
The current building is an assembly of other buildings. Each of the other buildings is defined by its id.

characteristics.description: This section defines some characteristics of a building which do not depend on a specific section such as 'IFC' or 'Revit' and which may be helpful for searches.

properties.title: This section adds roles which are specific for buildings to the existing roles for building envelopes.

items.description: The owners own the building at the moment indicated by the timestamp of this data. Each owner is identified by an id.
Architects offer to design the building. Each architect is identified by an id.

BIMmanager.description: The BIM manager MUST guarantee the uniqueness of the decentral identifiers. She is responsible for the database of the building at the moment indicated by the timestamp of this data. The BIM manager is identified by an id.

items.description: The planners provide assistance to the stakeholders, for example for the detailed planning in a domain like structural analysis or the technical building plant. Each planner is identified by an id.
Contractors offer to construct the whole building or parts of it. Each contractor is identified by an id.
Suppliers offer to supply components for the building. Each supplier is identified by an id.
Investors offer financial credits to the stakeholders or offer to buy the building from the owners. Each investor is identified by an id.
Tenants rent space in the building. Each tenant is identified by an id.
Public authorities grant permissions according to the current regulations. Each public authority is identified by an id.
Assesors offer to rate a building for example regarding its sustainability. Each assesor is identified by an id.
Facility managers are responsible for a good operation of the building. Each facility manager is identified by an id.

approvals.description: If the dataset for this building has been approved by an institution, this approval is specified here.

IFC.title: The data about a building can be stored in the open source format Industry Foundation Classes (IFC).

full.title: This section is used if the full data about the building is requested.

id.description: This id represents this set of full data about the building.

webAddress.description: The IFC file with full data about the building can be downloaded for some time from this URL.

explanation.description: An explanation of the status of the full data set in natural language.

formatting.description: The definition of IFC version which is used to format the IFC file. For example '4.1.0.0'.

created.description: The date when the file was created

parts.title: This section is used if parts of the data of the building are requested.

id.description: The GlobalId which each IFC entities can have as its first attribute. It is inherited from IfcRoot. This id represents the entity for which 'webAddress' provides the data.

webAddress.description: The data about this IFC entity can be downloaded for some time from this URL.

formatting.description: The definition of IFC version which is used to format the IFC file. For example '4.1.0.0'.

created.description: The date when the file was created

Revit.title: #TODO (Datei, API, Elements) The data about a building can be stored in the closed source format of Autodesk Revit.

LinkedData.title: #TODO (SPARQL-Endpunkt, Ontologien) The data about a building can be stored as linked building data.

characteristics.title: This section defines some characteristics of a building which do not depend on a specific section such as 'IFC' or 'Revit' and which may be helpful for searches.

location.title: This section defines the location of a building.

latitude.description: The latitude of the location of the building as a decimal number according to WGS 84.

longitude.description: The longitude of the location of the building as a decimal number according to WGS 84.

elevation.description: The elevation of the location of the building. It has the SI unit meter.

address.description: The address of the building. It consists for example of the street, the city, the county, the postal code and the country.

building.title: This section defines data about one building. It is an array so that various data sets about the building can be added as items.
